instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message:
I have a 3476 that had some liquid damage/corrosion under the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> which I replaced. Here some measurements: 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  =  12.57
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  =  5.02
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>  =  0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  = 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>  =  0.45
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = Pulsing from 0 - 0.59

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
Pin 12 <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.42  
Pin 21 <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.42 
Pin 23 VIN = 12.57
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL>  =  0

The <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Line goes from 0 to 5v and then turn off again. 
<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> checked seems OK, resistor and power going in same for <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
Found a short in <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> seems to be a trouble to test all C :P any ideas?

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message: It is power cycling. What is resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message: There is none its shorted as mentioned above.

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = Pulsing from 0 - 0.59

So no way it is fully shorted. Again, what is the resistance to GND?

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message:
Hi Duke,

I wrote -> "The <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Line goes from 0 to 5v and then turn off again", this measured on the fan's 5V pin

The <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> gives me 0.06 and a beep when measuring resistance to ground

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message: oh yes i forgot i measured that too that is correct its pulsing as well, and when I measure Short to GND I get a beep and 0.055 or 6

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message: I only have a 2.6 board here to compare but a good 2.6 CPU measures 80 Ohm to GND on CPU Vcore. You measured diode mode but at 0.05 that will pretty much be the same in Ohm. o very likely the CPU is fried.

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green & red light no fan
threads.message: OK thanks, gonna work on another board instead :)
